No, they cannot. The Ripple network has no central authority.
They did. Somebody said that Ripple couldn't have taken R3 to court first and I disagree.
"Bitcoin can be seen like a sort of cash for remote payments." Not with $4, $5, and $6 transaction fees.
"It is not clear why Ripple has such digital asset." $ XRP serves as a bridge currency and it helps secure the ledger by keeping out spam.
Regarding your confusion over how Ripple can help banks with compliance, they do it by providing software equipped to help with compliance..
There are more than 25 nodes on the network and they are not "all managed" by Ripple. I see 199 listed here:https://xrpcharts.ripple.com/#/topology
"We don’t see a protocol to decide who’s trusted. Who decides then?" With Ripple, you choose who to trust. The onus is on you.
Participants do not have to be "identified, authenticated and trusted" to operate in the Ripple network.
Ripple could have taken R3 to court for fraudulent misrepresentation & concealment.
